thread.title: Thrilling start to World Windsurfing Championships
thread.title_full: Thrilling start to World Windsurfing Championships

author: muscatdaily@apexmedia.co.om (Muscat Daily News)
title: Thrilling start to World Windsurfing Championships
text:
Follow us on Thrilling start to World Windsurfing Championships France’s Pierre Le Coq in action on the opening day of the RS:X World Windsurfing Championships at the Musannah Sports City Muscat Daily staff writer October 20, 2015 
In ideal conditions with breeze blowing at around 10-12 knots at the Musannah Sports City, the 2015 RS:X World Windsurfing Championships got off to an exciting start on Monday, thanks to some spectacular racing. 
China's Peina Chen emerged on top in the women's event among a field of 59 windsurfers after the conclusion of all the three races with three points. 
No 1 ranked Bryony Shaw of the UK was trailing in second spot with six points, while another title contender from Poland, Malgorzata Bialecka, was third with ten points. 
China’s Peina Chen competes during one of the three races on Monday 
France's Pierre Le Coq was the surprise leader among the 82 men, collecting four points from three races, while Poland's Piotr Myszka was second with six. Switzerland's Mateo Sanz Lanz was third with ten points, the same as of China's Aichen Wang. 
Racing in the men's and women's events was split into two fleets - blue and yellow - according to the windsurfers' rankings. 
The 26 year old Peina was unstoppable as she led in all the three races. A runner-up at the ISAF Sailing World Cup in Qingdao, China recently, Peina won the last race by an impressive one minute and six seconds. 
Speaking after her dominating performance, Peina said, “My increased fitness and my ability to sustain the pumping played a big part. Also, I spent the last two weeks training here, which helped me a lot. I am familiar with the conditions here, including the hot breeze.” 
“It is a great venue for this sort of an event as we have the accommodation and training venue right next to the sea. It becomes so convenient and easy and the sailing conditions are superb as well,” she said. 
In the men's fleet, racing was expectedly tight although the 9-10 knot shifty breeze proved a tactical challenge. 
Le Coq finished the day with two firsts and a second to go on top. The windsurfer from Brest, France said, “It was technically quite difficult on the race course, so I am pleased with my consistent performance. I was happy that I managed to be quite fast upwind, while downwind I sailed deep. Also, I like the conditions and I felt very comfortable out there today,” he said. “Getting a good start was very important and it worked out that way.” 
Racing continues on Tuesday with three more qualifying races for both fleets. After the concluding qualifying race, competitors will drop their worst race score. They will then be split into gold and silver fleets, to be determined by their overall positions. Similar content
